form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Reid (for himself, Mr. McConnell, Mr. Levin, and Mr. McCain) submitted the following resolution; which was considered and agreed to

form.official-title: Amending the Standing Rules of the Senate.

section.header: Bipartisan cloture on the motion to proceed
section.text: Rule XXII of the Standing Rules of the Senate is amended by inserting at the end the following:

subsection.text: If a cloture motion on a motion to proceed to a measure or matter is presented in accordance with this rule and is signed by 16 Senators, including the Majority Leader, the Minority Leader, 7 additional Senators not affiliated with the majority, and 7 additional Senators not affiliated with the minority, one hour after the Senate meets on the following calendar day, the Presiding Officer, or the clerk at the direction of the Presiding Officer, shall lay the motion before the Senate. If cloture is then invoked on the motion to proceed, the question shall be on the motion to proceed, without further debate.

section.text: Rule XXVIII of the Standing Rules of the Senate is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating paragraphs 2 through 9 as paragraphs 3 through 10, respectively;

subparagraph.text: in subparagraph (b), by striking paragraph (4) each place it appears and inserting paragraph (5); and

subsection.text: When a message from the House of Representatives is laid before the Senate, it shall be in order for a single, non-divisible motion to be made that includes—

paragraph.text: a motion to disagree to a House amendment or insist upon a Senate amendment;
a motion to authorize the Presiding Officer to appoint conferees (or a motion to appoint conferees).

subsection.text: If a cloture motion is presented on a motion made pursuant to subparagraph (a), the motion shall be debatable for no more than 2 hours, equally divided in the usual form, after which the Presiding Officer, or the clerk at the direction of the Presiding Officer, shall lay the motion before the Senate. If cloture is then invoked on the motion, the question shall be on the motion, without further debate.
